title: Send, Surrey
text:
Send is a <a href="villages%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">village</a> and <a href="civil%20parishes%20in%20England">civil parish</a> in the <a href="Guildford%20%28borough%29">Guildford borough</a> of the <a href="English%20county">English county</a> of <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a>. Send acquired its name during the <a href="Great%20Vowel%20Shift">Great Vowel Shift</a> from the word <a href="sand">sand</a>, which was extracted at various periods until the 1990s for construction and other purposes at pits in the outskirts of the parish. The north of Send is at the southern-eastern edge of the <a href="Bagshot%20Formation">Bagshot Formation</a>.
Send is <a href="buffer%20zone">buffered</a> by <a href="Metropolitan%20Green%20Belt">Metropolitan Green Belt</a> from other villages and towns except for the Grove Heath neighbourhood of <a href="Ripley%2C%20Surrey">Ripley</a>. A rural band of the village adjoins the <a href="River%20Wey">River Wey</a> including Cartbridge and Send Marsh – this land has been drained and the river tamed by sluices, the Broadmead Cut and the <a href="Wey%20and%20Godalming%20Navigations">Wey Navigation</a>. The vast majority of the built-up areas are not within an area of flood risk. Between the river and the navigation, in the far north of the parish, are the <a href="Papercourt">Papercourt</a> and Broad Mead <a href="Site%20of%20Special%20Scientific%20Interest">SSSIs</a>.
History.
Send appears in <a href="Domesday%20Book">Domesday Book</a> of 1086 as "Sande". It was held by Rainald (Reginald) from Alvred de Merleburgh (<a href="Marlborough%2C%20Wiltshire">Marlborough</a>). Its Domesday assets were: 20 <a href="hide%20%28unit%29">hide</a>s; 1 church, 10 <a href="plough">plough</a>s, 2 <a href="Mill%20%28grinding%29">mill</a>s worth £1 3s 6d, 5 <a href="fishery">fisheries</a> worth 4s 6d, of <a href="meadow">meadow</a>, <a href="woodland">woodland</a> for 160 <a href="hog%20%28swine%29">hog</a>s. It was headed by 41 households and had additionally fifteen serfs, although whether they had households or not is uncertain. It rendered £15 10s 0d per year to its overlords. In this case the <a href="lord%20of%20the%20manor">manorial lords</a> were simply recorded as Herbert; Reginald son of Erchenbald; and Walter, seemingly <a href="Anglo-Saxon%20England">Anglo-Saxon</a>. It was held at the time of the <a href="Norman%20Conquest">Norman Conquest</a> by Karli of Norton.
The parish saw a little-known skirmish. On 14 June 1497 the <a href="Cornish%20Rebellion%20of%201497">first Cornish Rebellion</a> was launched against <a href="Henry%20VII%20of%20England">Henry VII</a>; the rebels were marching from <a href="Cornwall">Cornwall</a> to Kent unbeknown to the King, and after passing <a href="Guildford">Guildford</a> they had a skirmish with some of the outposted royal troops on the road from Guildford to London. The troops fell back or were outmanoeuvred, for they had lost the rebels on the 16th and were looking for them on the <a href="Portsmouth%20Road">Portsmouth Road</a> again near Kingston when they were actually on the border of Kent. Old maps mark the place where the road crosses the stream which joins the Wey near Send as St. Thomas's Waterings.
Ripley was, at the time of the Domesday Book, a <a href="hamlet%20%28place%29">hamlet</a> of Send. In 1878 Ripley gained its own parish. The earliest official record, such as a <a href="Patent%20Roll">Patent Roll</a>, revealing its <a href="Manorialism">manor</a>'s existence is in 1279. Growth in ambition of the local nobility coupled with a large enough population led to the first place of worship being built at Ripley, to become a <a href="chapelry">chapelry</a> to <a href="Mary%20%28mother%20of%20Jesus%29">St Mary the Virgin</a>, around the year 1160.
<a href="Brickmaking">Brickfield</a>s were developed in the south of Send by the 1870s, and continued to be worked until at least 1911.
The <a href="Leese%20baronets">Leese baronets</a> "<a href="territorial%20designation">of Sendholme</a> in Send in the County of Surrey", who lived at the large house of that name in the village, bore a title created in 1908 for <a href="Joseph%20Leese">Joseph Leese</a>, <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28UK%29">Liberal</a> Member of Parliament for <a href="Accrington%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Accrington</a> from 1892 to 1910. The third Baronet was a <a href="Lieutenant-General">Lieutenant-General</a> in the <a href="Coldstream%20Guards">Coldstream Guards</a> and served as Commander-in-Chief of the Allied Land Forces in South-East Asia from 1944 to 1945 and as General Officer Commanding-in-Chief of the Eastern Command from 1945 to 1946.
Send was the base of the defunct 1950s <a href="Formula%20One">Formula One</a> and <a href="sports%20car">sports car</a> constructor <a href="Connaught%20Engineering">Connaught Engineering</a>.
Geography and transport.
Send is a <a href="dispersed%20settlement">lightly dispersed village</a> centred south-west from <a href="Charing%20Cross">Charing Cross</a> and south-west of junction 10 of the <a href="M25%20motorway">M25</a> and has a <a href="nucleated%20village">developed clustered centre</a> on the old course of the <a href="Portsmouth%20Road">Portsmouth Road</a> which bisects the highest settled part of the village, Burntcommon, which is on the start of rise of the <a href="London%20Clay">London Clay</a>. This road was relieved by the construction of a six-lane bypass, part of the <a href="A3%20road">A3 trunk road</a>, which now forms the long south-east border of the village. The other principal road is the <a href="A%20roads%20in%20Zone%202%20of%20the%20Great%20Britain%20numbering%20scheme">A247</a> Woking to West Clandon road which passes through the village from north to south.
The parish is bounded to the west and part of its northern side by the River Wey, which is controlled by sluices and has been expanded in capacity by a navigable channel running alongside, the Wey Navigation.
The nearest railway stations are at <a href="Clandon%20railway%20station">West Clandon</a>, on the <a href="New%20Guildford%20Line">New Guildford Line</a>, and <a href="Woking%20railway%20station">Woking</a>, on the <a href="South%20West%20Main%20Line">South West Main Line</a>, which offer frequent fast and semi-fast services to London.
Soil.
Send is on a gently rising patch of Bagshot Sand, with Cartbridge, like Ripley, on sand and <a href="gravel">gravel</a> of the lower Wey Valley; a southern part of the parish is on generally higher still London Clay.
Elevation.
Elevations range from <a href="Above%20Ordnance%20Datum">Above Ordnance Datum</a> in the south to at the far northern border on the <a href="Wey%20Navigation">Wey Navigation</a>.
Localities.
Cartbridge.
Cartbridge is a mostly amorphous locality that covers the western end of the village's main street, particularly where it turns to the north towards <a href="Woking">Woking</a>.
Send Marsh.
The neighbourhood is contiguous with the clustered, built-up estates of Boughton Court Avenue and the <a href="Portsmouth%20Road">Portsmouth Road</a> forming Burntcommon. For census analyses of the largest neighbourhoods in Surrey, in 2001 the county council opted to consider Burntcommon as a non-notable locality jointly with Send Marsh. On this basis its population at the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20Census%202001">United Kingdom Census 2001</a> was almost half of the village as a whole, at 1,937.
Send Marsh has Send's Grade II listed late 17th century <a href="manor%20house">manor house</a> by the <a href="village%20green">village green</a>. It is built of brown brick in <a href="English%20bond">English bond</a>. The hamlet has one public house, called the "Saddlers Arms", but no shops or church.
Unusually for Guildford schools it is within the admission priority area of Guildford's <a href="George%20Abbot%20School">George Abbot School</a> most years and the boundaries have not to date excluded it to be replaced by for instance closer areas of north-western <a href="Guildford">Guildford</a>.
Burntcommon.
Burntcommon is a locality of Send that directly adjoins Send Marsh. Its nearest town is <a href="Woking">Woking</a>, which lies approximately north-west.
Amenities.
Health and well-being.
The small Send Surgery on Send Road next to the Church Rooms closed in 2003 and reopened on Send Barns Lane as the modern Villages Medical Centre serving 7,000 people in Send, Ripley and the surrounding villages. The old surgery is now occupied by a beauty treatment business. The Old Hall, on Send Marsh Road, is now a residential care home.
Businesses.
The main route through the community runs <a href="boxing%20the%20compass">NE/SW</a>, the A247 Send Road, along which are scattered the shops, businesses and facilities.
These include the post office, a takeaway, diving shop/centre, a fireplace outlet, an independent funerals firm, a hairdressers, a microscope and measuring devices manufacturer, Ghost Production Studios, based at the Old Riding Stables on Send Hill, have worked with several well-known clients, including Paul Connelly, Ben Lovejoy, Sue Macmillan, Social, <a href="Satellite%20State">Satellite State</a>, <a href="Go%20West%20%28band%29">Go West</a>, <a href="Tony%20Hadley">Tony Hadley</a>, Heat Wave, Charlie Morgan, Mark Brizickey, <a href="Adam%20Wakeman">Adam Wakeman</a>, <a href="Victoria%20Beckham">Victoria Beckham</a>, <a href="Elton%20John">Elton John</a>, and <a href="Draven%20%28band%29">Draven</a>.
Recreation.
Send has a recreation ground, the Lancaster Hall and the Church Rooms. There are two <a href="pubs">pubs</a> in the village: "The New Inn" in Cartbridge, adjacent to the <a href="Wey%20Navigation">Wey Navigation</a> and "The Saddlers Arms" in Send Marsh.
Schools.
Send <a href="National%20school%20%28England%20and%20Wales%29">National School</a>, off Send Hill, was built in 1834 and enlarged in 1892. When the school closed, the building was converted to residential use. It is now known as The Old School.
Send Church of England Central School was built in 1939 but, with war imminent, its opening was delayed until 1941 in case the building was required for military use. During the planning process questions were raised in the House of Commons about the provision of adequate drainage. Initially conceived as a secondary school, it was built on a large plot of land with space for facilities including a light engineering workshop, a carpentry room, a domestic science room and a gymnasium, in addition to a vast playing field. Over time it became known as St Bede's and, from 1972, was relaunched as a middle school. Facilities grew to include two outdoor swimming pools.
Send Church of England (Foundation) First School was built in 1958.
Send's two schools formed the Federation of Send Church of England Schools on 29 March 2012.
Under its final title, St Bede's Church of England (Aided) Junior School buildings were demolished in Summer 2017 and a replacement building for 7– to 11-year-olds was erected on the Send First School site on Send Barns Lane.
Religion.
Church of England.
Send parish church is dedicated to St Mary the Virgin and dates from around 1220. The nave was rebuilt and the tower added in around 1485. New kitchen and toilet facilities were completed in 2002. A York stone path was laid in the churchyard in 2003. The church is a Grade II* listed building and is the oldest building still in use in Send. In January 2008 the church was voted Visitor/Leisure Attraction of the Year in the Guildford "Life with Style" awards, attracting 75% of the votes and beating the <a href="Royal%20Horticultural%20Society">Royal Horticultural Society</a> gardens at <a href="Wisley">Wisley</a>, <a href="Watts%20Gallery">Watts Gallery</a>, <a href="Guildford">Guildford</a> Tour Guides and Surrey Hills Llamas. In October 2008 the church received the Mayor of Guildford's Award for Access.
Roman Catholicism.
<a href="St%20William%20of%20York">St William of York</a> (<a href="Roman%20Catholic">RC</a>) church closed in 2007.
Evangelical.
Send <a href="Evangelism">Evangelical Church</a> opened in May 1974 using the former <a href="Congregational%20church">Congregational</a> chapel in Cartbridge, built in 1875.
War memorials.
Send has three such memorials.
A Celtic-style stone cross next to the Church Rooms on Send Road rises above these inscriptions:
"1914–1918 In memory of the men of this village who at the call of duty gave their lives their country. Faithful unto death."
The names of the fallen are:
A brick memorial mounted with a wrought iron "1914 1918" in the recreation ground near the corner of Send Road and Sandy Lane bears the words: "This recreation ground was purchased by public subscription and was opened on 1 June 1920 for the benefits of the inhabitants of Send as a memorial to the sailors and soldiers who fell and in grateful recognition of those in the village who took part in the Great War of 1914–1918. Trustees: S. S. Boorman, A. H. Lancaster, J. A. Shirer, W. M. Grant, F. W. Morgan Jones, W. G. Whitbourn."
A stone tablet on the north wall of the nave inside the parish church bears this inscription: "The peal of six bells was hung as a memorial to those of this parish who lost their lives in two world wars and as a thank offering for victory." The names listed are the same as on the Celtic-cross memorial but with the addition of five people "killed by enemy action": V. Bowers, H. C. Parsons, H. E. Privett, M. J. Privett and V. Privett. Members of the Privett family were killed on 21 August 1944 by the explosion of a <a href="V-1%20%28flying%20bomb%29">V1 flying bomb</a> which landed on their home at Burnt Common Cottages.
Demography and housing.
The <a href="United%20Kingdom%20Census%202011">United Kingdom Census 2011</a> reported Send's population to be 4,245, an increase of 107 since the 2001 census. The number of households was 1,665, an increase of 42 since the 2001 census.
Of the accommodation in the region, 28% was composed of detached houses, and 22.6% was composed of apartments.
The proportion of households in the civil parish who owned their home outright compares to the regional average of 35.1%. The proportion who owned their home with a loan compares to the regional average of 32.5%. The remaining % is made up of rented dwellings (plus a negligible % of households living rent-free).
Occupations.
The <a href="high%20street">high street</a> provides some professional occupations and technical businesses, the schools and nearby prison form most of the government merit services; other occupations existing in the parish include manufacturing, agriculture and food and leisure-related categories of employment. Nonetheless, the village demographically has a very high proportion of professionals and in relation to these, it is part of the <a href="London%20Commuter%20Belt">London Commuter Belt</a>, with the <a href="City%20of%20London">City of London</a> being the main destination by train from <a href="Woking">Woking</a>. The nearest entertainment and large retail premises are in Woking. A former landfill in Send is a 20 hectare plantation of short rotation coppice <a href="willow">willow</a>.
Occupations of the 2,114 workers between the ages of 16 and 74 were broken down in the 2011 census as follows:
Population over time.
Data for 1801–1961 is available at Britain Through Time. The loss of Ripley in 1878 ecclesiastically and in 1933 as a secular administrative unit (civil parish) represented almost half of the land area of the village.
Popular culture.
Music.
The Send Barns Orchestra, conducted by Jeremy Gilbert, are credited on the 1977 <a href="Anthony%20Phillips">Anthony Phillips</a> album "<a href="The%20Geese%20and%20the%20Ghost">The Geese and the Ghost</a>", large parts of which were recorded at his home in Send.
Film location.
In 1969, a scene for The Telling Bone episode of <a href="Catweazle">Catweazle</a>, featuring <a href="Geoffrey%20Bayldon">Geoffrey Bayldon</a>, filmed two backgrounds in Send: Church Lane using the <a href="lych%20gate">lych gate</a> and Send Parish Church and 1 Heath Farm Cottages, Tannery Lane as "Sam's Cottage". "Sam Woodyard" was played by <a href="Neil%20McCarthy%20%28actor%29">Neil McCarthy</a>. In 1999, scenes for <a href="The%20Mrs%20Bradley%20Mysteries">The Mrs Bradley Mysteries</a>, starring Dame <a href="Diana%20Rigg">Diana Rigg</a> and <a href="Neil%20Dudgeon">Neil Dudgeon</a>, were filmed in the churchyard.
In April 2009, scenes for a <a href="BBC">BBC</a> Drama production of <a href="Jane%20Austen">Jane Austen</a>'s "<a href="Emma%20%28novel%29">Emma</a>", adapted by <a href="Sandy%20Welch">Sandy Welch</a> and starring <a href="Romola%20Garai">Romola Garai</a>, <a href="Michael%20Gambon">Michael Gambon</a>, <a href="Jonny%20Lee%20Miller">Jonny Lee Miller</a>, <a href="Blake%20Ritson">Blake Ritson</a>, <a href="Dan%20Fredenburgh">Dan Fredenburgh</a>, <a href="Tamsin%20Greig">Tamsin Greig</a> and <a href="Rupert%20Evans">Rupert Evans</a>, were filmed in and around Send Parish Church.
In August 2012, Willow Drive was used to film scenes for <a href="Cuban%20Fury">Cuban Fury</a>, starring <a href="Nick%20Frost">Nick Frost</a>.
Prison.
Counterintuitively now named after the village is HMP Send, a women's prison on the site of a former isolation hospital. Following parish area reduction in the south the jail is now in the southern part of the parish of Ripley surrounded by farmland and woodland.
Sport.
Send's local <a href="association%20football">football</a> team is Send United. There is sailing on Papercourt Lake, which is owned by Papercourt Sailing Club. There is fishing on the <a href="River%20Wey%2C%20Surrey">River Wey</a> and in the nearby sandpits.
The Concorde Cricket Club, formerly the British Aerospace Cricket Club, is based at Sendholme on Potters Lane. Sendholme was the home of William Hargreaves Leese, who played for the <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> in the late 19th century.
Military residents and events.
Lieutenant-General <a href="William%20Evelyn%20%281723%E2%80%931783%29">William Evelyn</a> Colonel of the 29th Foot in the British Army and Member of Parliament for <a href="Helston%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Helston</a> (1767–74), a son of Sir <a href="John%20Evelyn">John Evelyn</a> of <a href="Wotton%2C%20Surrey">Wotton</a>, established his home at Send Grove, Church Lane, and he laid out the grounds. On his death, in 1783, it was bought by Admiral Sir <a href="Francis%20William%20Drake">Francis William Drake</a>, <a href="Governor%20of%20Newfoundland">Governor of Newfoundland</a> (1750–1752), second in command to <a href="George%20Brydges%20Rodney%2C%201st%20Baron%20Rodney">Rodney</a> in his victory of 1782 over <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20Joseph%20Paul%2C%20marquis%20de%20Grasetilly%2C%20comte%20de%20Grasse">De Grasse</a>. As Rear-Admiral, Drake flew his flag on HMS "Victory" from 26 September to 29 December 1780.
Flight Lieutenant Robin R Skene, one of the first members of the <a href="Royal%20Flying%20Corps">Royal Flying Corps</a>, was buried in the churchyard after crashing in his <a href="Bl%C3%A9riot%20XI">Blériot monoplane</a> shortly after take-off from <a href="RAF%20Netheravon">Netheravon</a>, Wiltshire, in 1914 on 12 August "en route" to Dover and France at the start of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>. He and mechanic R. Barlow were the first members of the Royal Flying Corps to die on active duty and among the first British casualties of the war.
Flooding.
Following flooding in the east of <a href="Send%20Marsh">Send Marsh</a> in 2000, when 16 properties were flooded to a depth of 1m, causing £600,000 of damage, a five-month <a href="Environment%20Agency">Environment Agency</a> (EA) scheme costing £400,000 began in February 2007 to reduce the risk from the <a href="East%20Clandon">East Clandon</a> stream. The stream was diverted in the 1870s for brick-making and could revert to its original course when flooded. Demonstrated by the relatively few properties affected, almost all built-up areas in the parish are not subject to flood risk according to EA data.
